answers.text: The foundation trust invests undistributed assets

qas.question: What is the goal of the Trust investments

answers.text: exclusive goal of maximizing the return on investment

qas.question: What are some of the negatives of the investments

answers.text: its investments include companies that have been criticized for worsening poverty in the same developing countries

qas.question: What type of company's are  critiscized

answers.text: These include companies that pollute heavily and pharmaceutical companies that do not sell into the developing world

qas.question: As a result of the critics what did the company announce

answers.text: the foundation announced in 2007 a review of its investments to assess social responsibility. It subsequently cancelled the review

qas.question: What is the exclusive goal of the developing world trust?
When did the company decide to review its lack of sales in the developing world?
What policy did the company cancel after 2007?

context: <a0_0>The foundation trust invests <b6_0>undistributed assets<b6_0/><a0_0/>, with the <a1_0>exclusive goal of <b5_0>maximizing the return on investment<b5_0/><a1_0/>. As a result, <a2_0>its investments include companies that have been criticized for worsening poverty in the same developing countries<a2_0/> where the foundation is attempting to relieve poverty. <a3_0>These include companies that pollute heavily and pharmaceutical companies that do not sell into the developing world<a3_0/>. In response to press criticism, <a4_0>the foundation announced in <b7_0>2007<b7_0/> a review of its investments to assess social responsibility. It subsequently cancelled the review<a4_0/> and stood by its policy of <b8_0>investing for maximum return<b8_0/>, while using voting rights to influence company practices.
